statement: As a lifelong Pennsylvanian, a conservative, and a supporter of the Second Amendment, I believe law‑abiding citizens should have broad access to firearms for self‑defense, sport, and tradition. At the same time, I think we strengthen those rights—not weaken them—by having commonsense safety measures like thorough background checks, responsible training, and tough penalties for criminals who misuse guns. The focus should be on keeping firearms out of the hands of dangerous people, not burdening responsible gun owners who follow the law.

statement: Having lived nearly a century and worked as a nurse, I’ve seen far too many lives cut short, and I believe we owe it to our communities to treat guns with at least the same seriousness we treat public health. The Second Amendment doesn’t have to mean a free-for-all; it can and should coexist with strong, common-sense regulations like universal background checks, safe storage requirements, and limits on weapons designed for mass killing. To my mind, real freedom includes the freedom to go to school, church, or the grocery store without fear of gun violence.

statement: I think people should be allowed to own guns because it’s part of our rights, but there need to be strong safety rules so fewer kids and innocent people get hurt. Things like background checks, safe storage laws, and required training seem fair, because they don’t take guns away from responsible owners, they just help protect lives.
